text: piecing together a new life 16 year-old
Muhammad arrived in Germany from Syria
in 2015 leaving his parents and siblings
behind in Turkey Muhammad was taken in
by the goat family in two years he's
learned to speak fluent German and he's
now thinking about his future well I'd
like to do something with electronics or
machinery when I finished school I'd
like to stay in this area I think it's
pretty and I think the local people are
very nice and I get along with them well
also I don't really want to live in a
big city so I think that this place is
perfect for me Mohammed's foster mom
Christina says taking in a refugee child
was a big decision we had a really good
feeling and that he is going to fit in
our family and in this moment we didn't
know anything about how he got to
Germany and we go to Europe what are the
circumstances does he still have a
family and what did he what did he see
and what it is simple
two years ago I was here in southern
Germany and witnessed on one weekend
alone how thousands of migrants arrived
at Munich Central Station at the time a
lot of Germans doubted whether the
country would be able to cope turns
American of course sepia chiffon does we
can do it but not everyone agreed he
involves book however the people took
this challenge as an opportunity as
Muhammad's story shows the road to
integration begins with learning the
language at this welcome class in a
local school refugee children from nine
different countries are doing just that
mrs. villa an immigrant herself from
Russia explained the system to me you
have to imagine that in a single year a
pupil hasslein as much German as an
elementary school people does in four
years after that he or she has to be
able to stay afloat to learn to find his
or her own way learn precise technical
terms in vocabulary in a specific field
immigration has been a key theme of this
election campaign and some politicians
think that Germany has taken on more
than it can handle
I'm from Burma Bart smart looking at the
labor market we have a long way to go
eighty percent of refugees are still
unemployed changing this will be very
difficult especially given that many of
these people don't speak German some are
even illiterate or lack the
qualifications required in our
high-performance society none of this
means that we shouldn't help people but
these are problems that do exist and
that we will have to deal with for at
least the next decade
back in Robyn's book Mohammed with the
support of the court family continues
his part in successfully integrating and
adapting to YouTube Nasim Hatami BBC
